title: Episode 107 – Elaine Blumenhein & Friends, Joyful Journey Hot Springs Spa
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
description: I’m good with what we’ve expressed. I’m just expressing gratitude. Thank you for being here. Thank you for contributing to the Wellbeing of others through your podcasts, the environmental and the social aspects of it.
full_transcript:
[5.6s - 6.2s]: Music

[11.3s - 16.8s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry.

[17.4s - 24.1s]: And today we're at Joyful Journey Hot Spring Spa, visiting with Elaine Blumenheim, High Lane.

[24.2s - 25.4s]: Right. Hi, Aaron.

[25.8s - 26.3s]: How are you doing today?

[26.3s - 32.8s]: Well, I'm doing well, especially now that you and Krasa are here. And thank you for being here.

[33.5s - 43.3s]: Thank you. We're really excited to be here. And I'm thrilled we have this opportunity to share the story of Joyful Journey with our audience.

[44.1s - 50.5s]: And we're going to be talking about a lot of different aspects of this beautiful, healing spa with natural hot springs, waters.

[50.5s - 55.0s]: And all that you've helped create here, Elaine, over the last several years.

[55.9s - 56.8s]: Thank you.

[58.2s - 68.5s]: Elaine Blumenheim acquired Joyful Journey Hot Spring Spa in 1998 when it was just three pools and still named after the town where it stands, mineral hot springs.

[69.1s - 78.9s]: She moved to the area in 1999 and since then, Elaine has added Yurt's Lodgerooms TPs, a large retreat center, a geodesic biodome greenhouse,

[78.9s - 85.4s]: and 11 unit labyrinths and more recently, two electric vehicle charging stations.

[85.7s - 91.6s]: Plus, numerous other aesthetic touches that have made this a true sanctuary for the soul.

[92.8s - 102.1s]: After living in the nearby spiritual mecca of Krasa on Colorado for 20 years, Elaine recently moved back to Boulder to spend more time with her family.

[103.1s - 111.2s]: Her blessings and prayers reach Joyful Journey on a daily basis as she continues to contribute to the day-to-day activities.

[112.1s - 118.8s]: And Elaine, calling this place a sanctuary, is so spot on it, it's so true.

[119.0s - 123.1s]: And I've personally been coming here since I was much younger.

[123.7s - 129.1s]: Over all these years, it's been such a wonderful haven and escape from the front range.

[129.1s - 135.5s]: And I wanted to ask you to describe to us, where are we and what's going on here.

[135.6s - 147.4s]: But first, let me just mention to our video audience, here we are sitting under the bright sun, which in the world of video production is something you basically don't ever do,

[147.7s - 151.1s]: because of the shadows and all the lighting that we're experiencing.

[151.7s - 158.8s]: But we thought, especially after the snowstorm we had yesterday, it would be wonderful just to be out in the sun and the elements with you all.

[158.8s - 163.8s]: And we felt with the water right behind us and in the background, the song Raid the Christo Mountains.

[164.7s - 168.1s]: And so that's our setting and so that's why we're out here in the sun.

[169.3s - 172.9s]: So tell us about Joyful Journey Hot Springs Spa.

[173.5s - 185.3s]: One thing I do want to say before I go back to the beginning is that I had a great general manager come and help me with all these things.

[185.3s - 192.0s]: So you've mentioned, like the aesthetics, adding things and making it such a special place.

[192.5s - 199.7s]: That's Theo Boudreau. And he has helped with the creation of so many things.

[200.8s - 202.6s]: So I want to give him credit.

[203.6s - 205.1s]: A big shout out to Theo.

[205.5s - 205.7s]: Yes.

[205.9s - 206.1s]: Great.

[206.5s - 211.6s]: So you want me to start at the beginning, how I ended up here.

[212.0s - 212.5s]: Let's do that.

[212.5s - 214.1s]: That's a long time ago.

[218.2s - 234.9s]: Well, I have to say, I kept getting messages from Spirit, from the Divine, that I needed to come down and bring feminine energy and wisdom into the waters in this place.

[234.9s - 241.0s]: That was way back in the, well, I moved down here in 99.

[244.0s - 252.0s]: And I had a vision for what I needed to do, but no idea how I was going to do it.

[254.5s - 258.2s]: And I just kept hearing that that's what I needed to do.

[258.2s - 261.5s]: And I walked the land many times.

[261.8s - 268.3s]: I have been told that this land had a curse on it by the Native Americans and nothing, no business would ever succeed.

[268.8s - 273.0s]: Because anything that had been started here as a business had not succeeded.

[273.8s - 278.1s]: So I said, well, I don't believe in curses for one thing.

[278.5s - 284.6s]: And I believe in working with the energies, the Spirit energies of the land and the waters.

[287.5s - 307.8s]: So I kept walking the land and trying to communicate with the ancients that were here and explaining that whatever I did would be for the benefit and the healing of others and make the water available for the healing qualities that it had.

[308.6s - 316.7s]: And at first I felt the energy of this kind of energy.

[317.2s - 320.8s]: Okay, let's see what you want to do. Let's see if you were able to do it.

[321.4s - 330.8s]: So I just kept walking around and talking with the Spirit and there's a wonderful place up here on meditation hill.

[330.8s - 337.2s]: We call it meditation hill, where the Aboriginal waters came through, I think thousands of years ago.

[337.2s - 340.8s]: And there's a natural circle of Travating Stone.

[342.0s - 360.6s]: So I would go up there to meditate and one day after I meditated, I felt the energies of the ancients that were dancing around me, like I had been accepted.

[362.5s - 365.5s]: And of course that wasn't all easy. I had no idea.

[366.4s - 372.2s]: I was, I want to say this, not to beg, but to let people know it's never too late.

[373.1s - 378.4s]: I started this whole project when I was 60.

[379.3s - 387.6s]: After both my kids went to college and a lot of things happened in my life to where I was guided to do this.

[387.6s - 396.2s]: And I had never done development. I have a degree in nursing from back in the dark ages.

[399.4s - 407.4s]: But I had to listen to the Spirit and I want people to know that if you listen, you will be given assistance.

[408.0s - 415.4s]: And it's not that they only talk to you at certain times. It's that we only listen at certain times.

[416.9s - 422.9s]: But when I walked the land, I could understand more of what I needed to do.

[424.2s - 431.2s]: And I learned a lot. And I knew, first of all, I listened to what people wanted.

[431.2s - 439.8s]: And they said, well, we love the healing waters, but we need overnight lodging so we can really take the waters for healing.

[440.3s - 447.3s]: So I thought, well, the quickest and most economical thing would be to put the yards up.

[448.1s - 455.5s]: And so we got the yards in. And then I, well, at the same time, I had to have a bathhouse for the yards.

[455.5s - 460.7s]: So then I put that in because this wasn't open 24 hours.

[461.4s - 472.3s]: And so I started with that. And people really loved them. And after a few years, they said, well, we kind of would like to have a private bathroom.

[472.9s - 476.6s]: And so we don't have to go out in the middle of the night.

[476.6s - 481.9s]: And I said, okay, well, I had to start on a hotel.

[482.5s - 488.5s]: Then I had friends who were doing yoga and doing conferences and healing work.

[488.5s - 491.3s]: And they wanted to come here to do events.

[495.7s - 501.3s]: So they kept coming and saying, when are you going to get this done so we can come down and do our retreat here?

[501.3s - 505.4s]: And it took me many years to plan it.

[506.6s - 509.1s]: And many years to really pull it together.

[510.0s - 518.5s]: And finally, we opened the Lodge and the Event Center in 2008.

[519.2s - 521.8s]: Here's another thing that I was helped with.

[525.7s - 536.7s]: 2007, I got a million dollar loan, a woman in the north part of the San Luis Valley.

[537.4s - 543.0s]: The banks in Salaita wouldn't even help me because they knew it wasn't going to succeed.

[543.5s - 546.0s]: I checked with the bank in Alamosa and it did.

[546.0s - 548.5s]: So I just wanted to put that out.

[548.8s - 549.7s]: Who would have thought?

[550.5s - 557.3s]: And then the next year, of course, 2008 was a big depression and the banks went down and all this happened.

[557.8s - 562.7s]: So I knew then that I'd just guided to do this and that we had a few years of struggle,

[562.7s - 564.8s]: but I've had so much help along the way.

[565.4s - 570.6s]: So when you decide to do something, you receive what you need.

[571.3s - 586.3s]: Yeah, this reminds me of this beautiful quote by Patanjali about the magic and the energy that conspires with us when we say yes to that intuitive impulse we're receiving.

[587.4s - 594.9s]: Maybe if I think of it, I'll include that quote in the show notes, see if I can pull that together.

[594.9s - 610.7s]: But you know, one of the things I'm really curious to ask you about Elaine is, I would say a lot of our audience has a deep spiritual practice and faith orientation, not all.

[611.7s - 626.0s]: And I'm very interested to hear more about this awakening and opening up in your journey to be able to listen while meditating on this land in this sacred area.

[626.7s - 632.1s]: Is that something you've been doing your whole life? Is it something that emerged over time?

[633.1s - 638.8s]: I don't think I really started my spiritual journey until I was in my 40s.

[639.0s - 646.8s]: I mean, I had a awakening some time to time and I learned through many different teachers.

[647.4s - 657.2s]: You know, in the 70s and 80s and bolder, there were many events and teachers and how do we follow all of that going on.

[657.2s - 669.0s]: I have had a teacher named Jonah through much of my adult life and I also have read the books by Eckhart Tolly.

[669.3s - 675.9s]: His books were like a Bible at my bedside for many years.

[676.8s - 683.1s]: So I've learned from many and tried to listen as much as I could.

[687.2s - 694.8s]: This is where I am. Sometimes I think, how in the world did I ever think I could do this? But it's happened.

[696.5s - 701.8s]: Now we do need to do a little because Seals done such a good job of helping me manage that.

[702.6s - 712.3s]: We now need more pools, we need more lodging, but it will never be like a huge resort. That's not what we're here for sure.

[713.3s - 720.8s]: I did it. I thought I was doing it to benefit the healing of others.

[721.2s - 728.9s]: And I became healed in the process. You never think that's going to happen.

[729.4s - 736.1s]: And we're never totally there, but there's always something more to learn and grow about.

[737.1s - 758.9s]: But my whole vision, mission statement, has been to allow the healing waters and the therapists we have, therapies we have to uplift the spirits and open the hearts of all who come.

[759.7s - 760.7s]: So beautiful.

[761.0s - 766.6s]: That they might remember who they are, where they came from and what they came to do.

[767.1s - 774.1s]: I don't really publish that part. But that's kind of in the background because we all are here for a purpose.

[775.1s - 777.4s]: And sometimes we forget that.

[778.4s - 794.0s]: And I think just being exposed to the healing waters, the mountains, the landscape, it just feels like sacred land and it puts you into, only if you want to, you can go as deep as you want.

[794.6s - 797.1s]: Or not. Just come for relax and visit.

[797.1s - 798.5s]: And that's it.

[799.4s - 808.5s]: You know, I feel so fortunate to have lived in Colorado for so many years with many different healing hot springs.

[809.2s - 818.6s]: And of course, in other parts of the country, other parts of the world, access isn't necessarily quite as easy as we have it around here.

[819.6s - 830.6s]: And that said, I am also struck that in so many traditions all around the planet, getting into the waters for healing is essential.

[830.8s - 847.9s]: Right. So the Mickva tradition of the hebraic culture, the ways that people interact with water in the Islamic world prior to going into the mosque, the bath houses of the Middle East Mediterranean region.

[847.9s - 861.9s]: And of course, hot springs around Turtle Island, the Americas here have been sacred to so many different tribes over time periods that some of us probably don't really even know.

[862.7s - 873.9s]: And I'm struck that more and more of us in our culture as our cultures in the process of healing are connecting to the water in this mindful and deep heartfelt way.

[874.9s - 881.1s]: And my own personal experience tells me that our relationship with water is critical. It's essential.

[881.9s - 886.2s]: And clearly you are embodying that and exhibiting and articulating that.

[886.8s - 896.6s]: I'm wondering what kinds of transformations have you seen in others who come here and experiences perhaps for the first time in their lives?

[897.0s - 898.8s]: Is that something you get to witness?

[898.8s - 912.3s]: Yes. I'm not here all the time anymore, but we, many times we hear stories about how it's affected people, how they have.

[912.9s - 926.0s]: And also some of our deeper therapies that we've had for them can also assist with the waters. It's amazing. It's such a joy to hear that.

[926.0s - 942.0s]: It makes me think, okay, this is why I was guided to do this really. And I'm sure Charmaine can tell you a lot more because she's in that area of the groups that she probably hears a lot more than I do right now.

[942.8s - 943.7s]: It's very healing.

[943.7s - 960.8s]: So maybe I'll just share with our audience that a little later in this episode. We're going to have Charmaine and Jason on as well talking about some of the programming here and an upcoming event that Jason's leading in a couple of months.

[960.8s - 972.4s]: It'll be about a month or so once we publish the episode. And so we're really excited to be able to share more information on all of that with you as well.

[973.4s - 989.7s]: And you know, I'm just so touched by the way that this healing spa has not only the waters to connect with, but also these sacred sites around the property.

[989.7s - 1000.6s]: And you mentioned the meditation circle that I wanted to ask you about the way you arrange the benches up there because I think that's also a very important.

[1000.8s - 1008.5s]: It might seem like a minor detail to some, but I think for many of us we would understand this to have great significance.

[1009.5s - 1016.6s]: I really tried to work with the energy of the ancients because they allowed me to be here.

[1020.0s - 1030.4s]: And so I put the, I found four concrete benches and I placed them in the four directions up on top of meditation.

[1032.8s - 1042.6s]: And people have, have gone up there many times. They've treated it as an altar. I would find all sorts of things that they put up there.

[1042.6s - 1063.1s]: So I know that they treated it as a very special sacred place. And I've always thought and we have always treated these waters as a very special gift from Mother Earth that we needed to honor.

[1063.1s - 1084.3s]: And we, we just a whole ambiance that we try to set up here. We try to create that. It's not always easy. You have people come here, they've got the weight of the world on their shoulders and they're cranky and they've driven hours to get to this place.

[1085.3s - 1094.3s]: And I've just told my friend to ask you have to just be patient and let them get to the waters as quickly as possible.

[1094.5s - 1101.4s]: And then they come out with a smile on their face usually and they're all happy. It's magical waters.

[1101.9s - 1109.5s]: Yeah, these waters are so magical and I love, by the way, we're staying in one of your lovely rooms here.

[1110.5s - 1130.5s]: And we're here for an event, the 11th annual San Luis Valley Seed Exchange event, which is just a wonderful gathering of folks, farmers, healers, seed savers, gardeners working on increasing resilience and sovereignty and stewardship and regeneration in our food systems.

[1130.5s - 1160.5s]: And in the room, of course, is a booklet that has some information about this place. And I was struck that it describes the minerals that are in the water in such detail and really goes into how these different constituent minerals that are naturally in these waters are helping with our mind body and soul.

[1161.5s - 1164.4s]: And I was wondering if you might speak to that a little bit.

[1164.9s - 1176.0s]: Well, yes, that's why people come. That's one of the reasons why they come. But it has the perfect balance of minerals for arthritis and bones and joints.

[1176.4s - 1190.5s]: We have many times in the past. I don't know. I haven't been here, but we would have people that climbed the mountains that were on bike rides and they would come here to soak after we've had a lot of athletes that are in the water.

[1190.5s - 1211.9s]: We would have come here for that. And we just, we have people that come here. I had one man that used to come three times a week and he said, this is my insurance for my arthritis. This keeps me healthy. I don't have to take any medications by come here three times a week. So it's got boron, calcium. I don't have the list in front of me.

[1212.5s - 1227.4s]: And it has a little lithium. And you know what lithium is for. So I used to have a young man here who was bipolar and he said, all I take is St. John's worth. And I come to your waters and soak whenever I can.

[1227.4s - 1244.3s]: And it keeps them. So it has, it has the minerals for digestion, for, it has a little arsenic in it. And that actually is what that keeps the bacteria count down.

[1244.3s - 1256.7s]: So we've never had any issues with people getting anything from here. And of course too much arsenic is good for you, but a little bit is really very good for you.

[1256.8s - 1269.3s]: And your brain and, you know, everything. So you name it. It's got something in the water. It's good for you. Your skin, the silica, you know, all kinds of things.

[1269.3s - 1273.0s]: Yeah. So, so lovely healing others.

[1274.0s - 1285.0s]: And the year spaces are magnificent. And there's also a grow dome, as we mentioned. And one of our sponsors is growing spaces who creates these

[1285.0s - 1293.5s]: new programs. And I was in there last summer on our way down to actually interview Lem in the Pugosa Springs.

[1294.0s - 1294.2s]: Oh.

[1294.4s - 1301.9s]: And it was such a joy. And maybe you could share this a little bit about what goes on in the grow domes throughout the year.

[1302.3s - 1310.9s]: Well, it's some, you know, I originally put it there because I thought it could be a place to grow food and flowers.

[1310.9s - 1324.3s]: I always wanted flowers in the bathhouse, in the places around because flowers is such a pure form of spirit energy that's given to us.

[1325.1s - 1332.1s]: You know, how can you not feel wonderful and uplifted when you really look at a perfect flower?

[1332.1s - 1332.8s]: Yeah.

[1333.4s - 1342.8s]: So, and I decided to design the beds in the greenhouse in the shape of a medicine wheel.

[1343.0s - 1343.3s]: Uh-huh.

[1344.1s - 1357.5s]: Because of the connection to the ancients and also because it seemed to be the most logical, because by making those pathways you could reach across all of them to do the work.

[1357.5s - 1369.0s]: Now, it's been hard to find people to be consistent with what I really needed to do with the greenhouse.

[1369.2s - 1371.1s]: Right now it's in very good shape.

[1371.5s - 1373.9s]: But people come and go in the valley.

[1374.3s - 1378.7s]: And so you can get it looking really good for a few years and then boom, they're gone.

[1379.0s - 1384.0s]: And then, okay, who's kind of take care of the greenhouse now. That's kind of the way it goes.

[1384.0s - 1391.3s]: But I wanted to have it to grow food and flowers and herbs.

[1391.8s - 1396.3s]: And it has amazing, what's that?

[1397.9s - 1400.3s]: Anyway, herb gardens in here.

[1400.3s - 1400.3s]: 

[1401.3s - 1405.7s]: And then a little nestership, you can just pick and put it in your mouth.

[1405.9s - 1406.8s]: Oh, I love nesterships.

[1407.0s - 1408.2s]: The others are so great.

[1409.2s - 1411.0s]: It's always a work in progress.

[1411.0s - 1412.7s]: Yeah, yeah, of course.

[1414.3s - 1419.7s]: Well, and we mentioned earlier that behind us are the Songre de Cristo mountains.

[1419.9s - 1425.7s]: And of course, we're here in the San Luis Valley, which I understand is the largest sub-alpine valley in the world.

[1426.7s - 1428.6s]: The elevation here is...

[1429.4s - 1430.0s]: 7700.

[1430.8s - 1431.5s]: 7700 feet.

[1431.5s - 1432.5s]: According to the topo.

[1433.0s - 1433.1s]: Yeah.

[1433.1s - 1445.2s]: And what's this valley like in terms of its history and significance in these Songre de Cristo mountains behind us?

[1445.9s - 1448.8s]: What does this place bring to mind for you?

[1450.4s - 1456.1s]: Well, I'm not sure with the ancients it was a very different place.

[1456.9s - 1460.2s]: Probably a lot of buffalo, a lot of tall grasses.

[1461.3s - 1466.9s]: And I think most all the indigenous tribes that were within...

[1467.6s - 1469.2s]: I don't know how close.

[1469.3s - 1473.8s]: They probably journeyed through the valley and partakeed in the hot springs.

[1474.6s - 1480.9s]: And there are several hot springs kind of on this journey through Clareu down to Ojo Caliente.

[1481.8s - 1483.8s]: That's outside of the Taures area.

[1483.8s - 1484.1s]: Yes.

[1484.5s - 1486.4s]: So, Clareu from...

[1486.4s - 1490.2s]: I don't know where in Colorado, but Clareu down into New Mexico.

[1490.8s - 1491.0s]: Yes.

[1491.4s - 1496.6s]: And a lot of people do the hot springs loop or the hot springs journey and they stop along the way.

[1498.3s - 1499.9s]: Which I won't name all of them.

[1500.2s - 1501.4s]: No, we'll have to name all of them.

[1501.6s - 1502.5s]: But it is one...

[1502.5s - 1503.3s]: I mean, there really are...

[1503.3s - 1506.1s]: There's so many wonderful hot springs throughout this region.

[1506.6s - 1512.9s]: Yeah, but I don't think it was a place that was settled that much.

[1513.5s - 1518.3s]: We don't find a lot of traces of where they actually lived here.

[1519.1s - 1522.3s]: There have been very few artifacts found on this land.

[1523.0s - 1529.8s]: When they did do some excavating at one point, they found a mammoth bone.

[1530.0s - 1530.6s]: A mammoth bone?

[1530.9s - 1533.1s]: Yeah, and so I have that at one point.

[1533.3s - 1534.1s]: I'll bring it down here.

[1534.2s - 1535.5s]: I just don't want to lose it.

[1536.0s - 1539.3s]: I have to make sure it's well taken, Carol, when I do.

[1539.3s - 1545.9s]: But I think they probably came here for healing and then went on and came out other places.

[1546.5s - 1546.6s]: Yeah.

[1547.0s - 1551.9s]: But it is said that this was a valley of peace, a bloodless valley.

[1552.3s - 1556.6s]: So even though at least until the Spaniards came here,

[1558.9s - 1563.2s]: even though there were a lot of tribes that came here, I think they laid down their weapons

[1563.2s - 1567.7s]: because they felt the harmony and the healing waters.

[1568.4s - 1568.6s]: Yeah.

[1569.0s - 1571.1s]: It wasn't a place for war.

[1571.5s - 1572.2s]: Yeah, yeah.

[1572.2s - 1577.3s]: I've heard that said about this area and a few other areas in the Rocky Mountains

[1577.3s - 1583.4s]: with the healing hot spring water that, yeah, even if tribes were warring,

[1584.2s - 1588.2s]: they in those locations would be only in peace together.

[1588.9s - 1589.2s]: Mm-hmm.

[1589.3s - 1589.7s]: It's amazing.

[1589.7s - 1590.5s]: Mm-hmm.

[1591.0s - 1593.0s]: If only we could do that again.

[1593.9s - 1594.8s]: Well, maybe we can.

[1595.8s - 1596.9s]: Maybe we can.

[1598.0s - 1602.7s]: Well, I want to remind our audience that this is the Why on Earth Community Podcast.

[1603.0s - 1604.4s]: I'm your host, Aaron William Perry.

[1604.7s - 1612.7s]: And today we're visiting with Elaine Blumenheim, who is the owner proprietor of Joyful Journey Hot Springs Spa.

[1613.7s - 1616.6s]: And you can get to Joyful Journey's website.

[1616.9s - 1618.9s]: It's joyfuljourneyhotsprings.com.

[1619.3s - 1623.7s]: On Facebook, it's Joyful Journey Hot Springs on Instagram the same.

[1624.6s - 1627.4s]: And of course, we'll put all these links in the show notes.

[1628.2s - 1633.9s]: And I'd like to give a very special thanks to our sponsors who make this podcast series possible.

[1634.7s - 1637.6s]: This, of course, includes Joyful Journey Hot Springs Spa.

[1638.6s - 1644.3s]: You're one of our most recent sponsors to join the Why on Earth Community in our work.

[1644.5s - 1646.0s]: And it's really appreciated, Elaine.

[1646.2s - 1646.7s]: Thank you for that.

[1646.7s - 1648.2s]: We appreciate you being here.

[1649.2s - 1661.0s]: And our sponsors also include Earth Coast Productions, the LIDGE Family Foundation, Alpine Botanicals, Purium, Earth Hero, Liquid Trainer, Vera Herbles,

[1661.0s - 1671.0s]: Growing Spaces, Soil Works, Earthwater Press, Dr. Bronners, 1% for the planet, and Walei Waters.

[3516.9s - 3518.5s]: And it's something that's been on my mind for a while.

[3518.7s - 3523.5s]: I actually studied the eco psychology movement in great depth about 20 years ago.

[3524.0s - 3532.1s]: And I'm thoroughly convinced that an intimate connection with nature, with the living realities of the world.

[3532.1s - 3537.9s]: And the fact that the whole world is a part of this planet, Gaia, that we all share is actually essential to our psychospiritual health and well-being.

[3538.6s - 3544.9s]: And I would love to hear more about what you've done and what you're thinking about doing going forward.

[3545.6s - 3549.8s]: Without question, I believe with you, the woods work, nature heals.

[3550.3s - 3559.1s]: And it is something that I had to do with my recovery journey was, I used to work shift work, so I'd work eight days at a time and six days off.

[3559.1s - 3567.6s]: So I feel like it was like going to the woods to heal for eight days and then I just wrecked myself for six, you know, for about five of those days.

[3568.3s - 3577.9s]: And it wasn't until I did get a little stretch of sobriety and I started to realize that the earth was trying to heal me every time I went to work.

[3578.5s - 3582.2s]: And I was like, oh my gosh, it was knocking on my door.

[3582.6s - 3585.9s]: The entire time just going, hey, this is it.

[3586.3s - 3587.8s]: This is where you get better.

[3587.8s - 3595.9s]: And that ended up becoming what I think of when I think of what is holding me and what is bigger than me.

[3596.8s - 3608.2s]: And that kept me working in that industry for a very long time, though the work was so very difficult and the humans that we work with had so much to deal with.

[3609.2s - 3627.8s]: The reward was incredibly worth it because taking people out of city life or whatever their ailment might have been and placing them there and sharing food with them and preparing it while sitting in the dirt and getting it between your toes, it's everything.

[3627.8s - 3632.8s]: And it takes us back to something that our bodies know and are programmed for.

[3634.9s - 3637.4s]: It's as though we only recently forgot this.

[3638.2s - 3643.8s]: And it was so much fun to always ask students, like, how do you feel now that you've been out here for a week and everything?

[3644.1s - 3645.5s]: Oddly, this feels like being home.

[3646.3s - 3649.1s]: And it's like, right, we haven't been inside houses that long.

[3649.7s - 3650.6s]: This is home.

[3651.7s - 3655.5s]: And once you can get past the bugs, they're actually quite cute.

[3655.8s - 3656.0s]: It's okay.

[3656.9s - 3670.0s]: But it was such a special time and place and so much more went into my own growth and healing from that than I think I could ever have given the kiddos that I worked with or the young adults.

[3671.3s - 3678.2s]: And because of that, also what you talked about yesterday in connection with the soil resonated so deeply.

[3679.0s - 3684.8s]: And I think that's one of the first things I did when I came out here is I whipped my shoes off and put my feet in the dirt and started walking through grass.

[3685.0s - 3686.3s]: I think that's how we met.

[3688.4s - 3693.2s]: And yesterday I wanted to go bury my hands and feet in the dirt and just sit there for a while.

[3695.8s - 3715.6s]: There is that that transparency and that acclimation to the earth that you're standing on and to be connected to it is to feel a sense of calm and hope when all of the plastic things that are booping and beeping at you are going wild and crazy.

[3715.8s - 3718.3s]: It's just a matter of being willing to put them down.

[3719.1s - 3720.8s]: And I'm not going to lie to you.

[3721.2s - 3723.0s]: I still struggle with the screens myself.

[3723.3s - 3723.8s]: Still an addict.

[3725.6s - 3726.8s]: So me too.

[3727.4s - 3727.7s]: Yeah, yeah.

[3728.7s - 3732.4s]: And we have brought up that joyful journey is an oasis.

[3732.6s - 3733.9s]: I mean it's out in the middle of nowhere.

[3734.1s - 3736.9s]: You're 15, 20 minutes from any town or activity.

[3737.5s - 3740.0s]: And when people get here, they're in awe.

[3740.4s - 3741.8s]: We don't have TVs in the rooms.

[3741.9s - 3743.5s]: We don't have refrigerators in the rooms.

[3745.5s - 3749.8s]: Elaine purposely created this atmosphere to connect with nature.

[3750.6s - 3752.8s]: And that's what people need to do more often, absolutely.

[3753.2s - 3756.8s]: Especially when they've been isolated the last year in their own homes.

[3757.0s - 3757.5s]: Yeah, absolutely.

[3757.8s - 3757.8s]: 

[3759.9s - 3762.1s]: So should you come to this retreat?

[3762.5s - 3762.7s]: Yeah.

[3763.1s - 3773.5s]: We are also going to be walking the grounds out on our great and blessed labyrinth and taking some time to really recognize what it means to do.

[3773.5s - 3779.4s]: And to take steps and through that hopefully connect the earth a little bit more.

[3779.9s - 3786.1s]: We're also planning on taking a little trip out to the dunes and to be out in the sand and to be in the breeze.

[3786.5s - 3789.8s]: And maybe we'll even sit down there for a little while for meditation.

[3806.0s - 3809.1s]: I think we've got some folks that are coming out from Florida even.

[3809.4s - 3815.9s]: So from all over the country that through these screens that I mentioned and trying to demonize just a little bit,

[3816.0s - 3826.6s]: could be a way for them to actually connect through things like Facebook and to continue to encourage each other to create respite to find sanctuary.

[3826.6s - 3829.4s]: And maybe find them put their way back here in an annual basis.

[3830.3s - 3831.2s]: Great idea.

[3831.8s - 3832.4s]: Great idea.

[3833.1s - 3842.2s]: So the sand dunes, this is the Great Sand dunes National Monument, which is not too many miles away from where we are sitting currently.

[3842.9s - 3853.7s]: And one of the things I love mentioning about the sand dunes is that this is one of the locations the original Star Wars movies were shot for the planet Tatooine.

[3853.7s - 3867.1s]: And I realize thinking about the Star Wars scenes, right, because like the Ewok, the Endor Moon, that was a lot of that was shot on the Pacific coast around the Redwoods.

[3867.3s - 3872.1s]: The Snow Planet of Hoth, a lot of that was shot up in Scandinavia.

[3872.5s - 3881.7s]: So believe it or not, Star Wars is actually sort of this natural history of our planet around the time of the 1970s and 1980s.

[3893.6s - 3896.5s]: Yeah, well, we really like bringing up Star Wars down again.

[3897.5s - 3905.0s]: But you know, one of the things you were saying earlier reminds me of another reference that ought to be common to many of us.

[3905.0s - 3912.0s]: And it's a scripture reference about Seek and You Shall Find, Ask and You Shall Receive Knock and It Shall Be Open to You.

[3912.1s - 3915.2s]: And I've heard you both using this kind of language here over the last few minutes.

[3915.9s - 3926.8s]: And part of the magic that I'm feeling coming through what you're creating together is it is probably opening doors for people that will be life changing.

[3926.8s - 3939.5s]: And to be able to create and offer that sort of transformational experience to me is so loudable and so important in these times in which we're living together.

[3940.7s - 3941.6s]: Thank you.

[3941.8s - 3943.9s]: Yeah, it's an opportunity.

[3946.1s - 3947.5s]: It's needed.

[3948.2s - 3952.7s]: And we are focusing on caregivers and health care workers on this one.

[3953.8s - 3955.1s]: Other people need it too.

[3955.9s - 3966.9s]: And we hope to increase that demography over the course of the number of retreats we're able to contribute to the well-being of others.

[3967.3s - 3968.5s]: A restorative retreat.

[3969.0s - 3972.8s]: That's it's, yeah, I'm looking forward to it.

[3972.9s - 3973.4s]: Yes, indeed.

[3973.4s - 3981.6s]: That reminds me of another thing we were talking about yesterday about how Joseph Campbell called George Lucas one of his best students.

[3981.6s - 3982.8s]: That was incredible.

[3983.4s - 3984.2s]: I didn't know that either.

[3984.6s - 3997.0s]: And happened to be a fan of both both those people because the Joseph Campbell's and the hero's journey is something that we used throughout the wilderness experience.

[3997.0s - 3999.6s]: And something I think about on a daily basis.

[4000.5s - 4004.7s]: And this retreat could be your call to adventure.

[4005.8s - 4013.9s]: And there will be things that will be happening, like identifying dragons and hopefully finding some people with some wisdom to share.

[4014.7s - 4017.1s]: That will be that life changing thing.

[4017.4s - 4021.7s]: And you can take this on a return to the people that you care about.

[4023.0s - 4023.9s]: That's exciting.

[4025.7s - 4028.3s]: I've got a big smile thinking about all of this.

[4029.3s - 4034.4s]: You know, I want to be sure that we mention there is a special call to action for our audience.

[4034.4s - 4042.8s]: And of course, if you're a health care worker, if you're in that field, please check out the upcoming event.

[4042.9s - 4048.1s]: This is joyfuljourneyhotsprings.com, art of well-being, where you'll find the information.

[4048.1s - 4063.2s]: And for others, maybe who aren't in this line of work, but would like to support what's happening, there is a call to action to help support folks who maybe can't afford the full freight of the event.

[4063.6s - 4068.1s]: And Charmaine, if you would, I wanted to ask you to speak to that a bit in more detail.

[4068.8s - 4069.5s]: Yes, thank you.

[4069.5s - 4079.7s]: So we've already received a couple of letters, a handful of letters from people who are in desire of attending this retreat.

[4081.6s - 4085.5s]: For one reason or another who are not able to afford the full cost.

[4086.4s - 4098.6s]: And I believe there are lots of people out there who are interested in helping our health care workers who have shown so much strength and fortitude and perseverance this past year.

[4099.3s - 4105.9s]: And our caregivers who have taken care of our loved ones when we couldn't be there for them.

[4106.5s - 4120.1s]: I have no doubt that there are people out there who would be interested in sponsoring people to come here, get some respite, get some tools, additional tools, so that again they can go back and take care of the people we care about.

[4121.2s - 4134.0s]: On the website, the Art of Wellbeing, there is a link that you can click on or you can contact me directly and at Joyful Journey Hot Springs Spa.

[4134.9s - 4138.7s]: And we can talk about how to sponsor someone to attend the event.

[4139.1s - 4141.1s]: Beautiful, that's so wonderful Charmaine.

[4141.1s - 4152.6s]: And I also want to mention that Jason, your work, Grateful Moves, folks can find out more information about that at GratefulMoves.com.

[4152.7s - 4155.2s]: And that's Grateful spelled with the number eight.

[4155.5s - 4159.1s]: So GR8FULMoves.com.

[4159.6s - 4162.8s]: And we'll put all these links in the show notes, of course.

[4164.4s - 4169.0s]: My goodness, my friends, it's such a pleasure to be able to visit with you today.

[4169.6s - 4178.7s]: And before we sign off with this episode, I want to invite each of you, if there's anything else you'd like to say before we close for now.

[4180.5s - 4182.1s]: I think we've wrapped it up, brawl.

[4182.2s - 4187.0s]: Yeah, I'm good with what we've expressed. I'm just expressing gratitude.

[4187.5s - 4188.3s]: Thank you for being here.

[4188.3s - 4197.2s]: Thank you for contributing to the well-being of others through your podcasts, the environmental and the social aspects of it.

[4197.3s - 4200.9s]: Thank you. I've listened to quite a few and I think you're doing a bang up job.

[4201.6s - 4202.7s]: Getting the word out.

[4204.0s - 4206.8s]: And thank you for including Joyful Journey in the process.

[4207.9s - 4208.8s]: Thank you.

[4209.0s - 4210.2s]: Well, thank you, Charmaine.

[4210.2s - 4215.9s]: And I tell you what, I really enjoy this podcasting thing.

[4216.0s - 4220.2s]: And it was not a premeditated planned deal.

[4220.3s - 4224.1s]: We just started Ardham at Earth Coast Productions and I Ardham's on our board of directors.

[4224.8s - 4228.3s]: We were visiting some farms and he does a lot of videography work.

[4228.4s - 4232.5s]: And we thought, well, let's start introducing people and see what happens in the low-bohel before we knew it.

[4232.6s - 4233.8s]: We have this little series going.

[4234.3s - 4240.4s]: And I'll tell you the key is interview really interesting people doing really important work.

[4240.5s - 4243.4s]: And the rest seems to take care of itself.

[4243.9s - 4250.5s]: And so it's a real joy and an honor and a privilege to be able to do that work that we're doing.

[4251.0s - 4260.0s]: And I also wanted to mention for sure that Jason, you shared in your also a podcaster and have a podcast resource out there for folks too.

[4260.1s - 4262.9s]: If you wouldn't mind just sharing those details, that would be great.

[4262.9s - 4269.2s]: Yeah, I actually also started a podcast that wasn't really a super planned out thing.

[4269.8s - 4286.0s]: Over the pandemic called Recovery for All because I am also involved with another organization called Namaste Sober that has this nice little beautiful phrase that I am also running with.

[4286.2s - 4287.8s]: And that is everybody's recovering from something.

[4287.8s - 4303.2s]: So there are so many different ways in which that we can talk about recovery, be it from the traditional substance abuse kind of track to whether or not you're recovering well from doing lots of exercise and activity.

[4303.6s - 4308.7s]: Because for those of us who maybe do quit the substance is sometimes we overdo it with movement.

[4309.7s - 4312.2s]: And it can be good to heal in other ways.

[4312.7s - 4318.3s]: So all are welcome and it is open for exploration.

[4321.0s - 4323.1s]: You can also find that through the website.

[4323.5s - 4324.7s]: Okay, it's your grateful moves.

[4325.0s - 4326.3s]: Correct, your grateful moves.

[4326.9s - 4333.6s]: And I'm also on Spotify and I believe I believe I'm through to Apple as well now for podcasts.

[4335.8s - 4342.4s]: And there will be a link that is also to the registration for this retreat through my website as well.

[4342.6s - 4347.8s]: So if you happen to be looking into what I'm all about first, you don't have far to go.

[4353.9s - 4358.4s]: Well, thanks to both of you Jason and Charmaine, it's a joy visiting with you.

segments.text: Music
Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry.
And today we're at Joyful Journey Hot Spring Spa, visiting with Elaine Blumenheim, High Lane.
Right. Hi, Aaron.
How are you doing today?
Well, I'm doing well, especially now that you and Krasa are here. And thank you for being here.
Thank you. We're really excited to be here. And I'm thrilled we have this opportunity to share the story of Joyful Journey with our audience.
And we're going to be talking about a lot of different aspects of this beautiful, healing spa with natural hot springs, waters.
And all that you've helped create here, Elaine, over the last several years.
Thank you.
Elaine Blumenheim acquired Joyful Journey Hot Spring Spa in 1998 when it was just three pools and still named after the town where it stands, mineral hot springs.
She moved to the area in 1999 and since then, Elaine has added Yurt's Lodgerooms TPs, a large retreat center, a geodesic biodome greenhouse,
and 11 unit labyrinths and more recently, two electric vehicle charging stations.
Plus, numerous other aesthetic touches that have made this a true sanctuary for the soul.
After living in the nearby spiritual mecca of Krasa on Colorado for 20 years, Elaine recently moved back to Boulder to spend more time with her family.
Her blessings and prayers reach Joyful Journey on a daily basis as she continues to contribute to the day-to-day activities.
And Elaine, calling this place a sanctuary, is so spot on it, it's so true.
And I've personally been coming here since I was much younger.
Over all these years, it's been such a wonderful haven and escape from the front range.
And I wanted to ask you to describe to us, where are we and what's going on here.
But first, let me just mention to our video audience, here we are sitting under the bright sun, which in the world of video production is something you basically don't ever do,
because of the shadows and all the lighting that we're experiencing.
But we thought, especially after the snowstorm we had yesterday, it would be wonderful just to be out in the sun and the elements with you all.
And we felt with the water right behind us and in the background, the song Raid the Christo Mountains.
And so that's our setting and so that's why we're out here in the sun.
So tell us about Joyful Journey Hot Springs Spa.
One thing I do want to say before I go back to the beginning is that I had a great general manager come and help me with all these things.
So you've mentioned, like the aesthetics, adding things and making it such a special place.
That's Theo Boudreau. And he has helped with the creation of so many things.
So I want to give him credit.
A big shout out to Theo.
Yes.
Great.
So you want me to start at the beginning, how I ended up here.
Let's do that.
That's a long time ago.
Well, I have to say, I kept getting messages from Spirit, from the Divine, that I needed to come down and bring feminine energy and wisdom into the waters in this place.
That was way back in the, well, I moved down here in 99.
And I had a vision for what I needed to do, but no idea how I was going to do it.
And I just kept hearing that that's what I needed to do.
And I walked the land many times.
I have been told that this land had a curse on it by the Native Americans and nothing, no business would ever succeed.
Because anything that had been started here as a business had not succeeded.
So I said, well, I don't believe in curses for one thing.
And I believe in working with the energies, the Spirit energies of the land and the waters.

So I kept walking the land and trying to communicate with the ancients that were here and explaining that whatever I did would be for the benefit and the healing of others and make the water available for the healing qualities that it had.
And at first I felt the energy of this kind of energy.
Okay, let's see what you want to do. Let's see if you were able to do it.
So I just kept walking around and talking with the Spirit and there's a wonderful place up here on meditation hill.
We call it meditation hill, where the Aboriginal waters came through, I think thousands of years ago.
And there's a natural circle of Travating Stone.
So I would go up there to meditate and one day after I meditated, I felt the energies of the ancients that were dancing around me, like I had been accepted.
And of course that wasn't all easy. I had no idea.
I was, I want to say this, not to beg, but to let people know it's never too late.
I started this whole project when I was 60.
After both my kids went to college and a lot of things happened in my life to where I was guided to do this.
And I had never done development. I have a degree in nursing from back in the dark ages.
But I had to listen to the Spirit and I want people to know that if you listen, you will be given assistance.
And it's not that they only talk to you at certain times. It's that we only listen at certain times.
But when I walked the land, I could understand more of what I needed to do.
And I learned a lot. And I knew, first of all, I listened to what people wanted.
And they said, well, we love the healing waters, but we need overnight lodging so we can really take the waters for healing.
So I thought, well, the quickest and most economical thing would be to put the yards up.
And so we got the yards in. And then I, well, at the same time, I had to have a bathhouse for the yards.
So then I put that in because this wasn't open 24 hours.
And so I started with that. And people really loved them. And after a few years, they said, well, we kind of would like to have a private bathroom.
And so we don't have to go out in the middle of the night.
And I said, okay, well, I had to start on a hotel.
Then I had friends who were doing yoga and doing conferences and healing work.
And they wanted to come here to do events.
So they kept coming and saying, when are you going to get this done so we can come down and do our retreat here?
And it took me many years to plan it.
And many years to really pull it together.
And finally, we opened the Lodge and the Event Center in 2008.
Here's another thing that I was helped with.
2007, I got a million dollar loan, a woman in the north part of the San Luis Valley.
The banks in Salaita wouldn't even help me because they knew it wasn't going to succeed.
I checked with the bank in Alamosa and it did.
So I just wanted to put that out.
Who would have thought?
And then the next year, of course, 2008 was a big depression and the banks went down and all this happened.
So I knew then that I'd just guided to do this and that we had a few years of struggle,
but I've had so much help along the way.
So when you decide to do something, you receive what you need.
Yeah, this reminds me of this beautiful quote by Patanjali about the magic and the energy that conspires with us when we say yes to that intuitive impulse we're receiving.
Maybe if I think of it, I'll include that quote in the show notes, see if I can pull that together.
But you know, one of the things I'm really curious to ask you about Elaine is, I would say a lot of our audience has a deep spiritual practice and faith orientation, not all.
And I'm very interested to hear more about this awakening and opening up in your journey to be able to listen while meditating on this land in this sacred area.
Is that something you've been doing your whole life? Is it something that emerged over time?
I don't think I really started my spiritual journey until I was in my 40s.
I mean, I had a awakening some time to time and I learned through many different teachers.
You know, in the 70s and 80s and bolder, there were many events and teachers and how do we follow all of that going on.
I have had a teacher named Jonah through much of my adult life and I also have read the books by Eckhart Tolly.
His books were like a Bible at my bedside for many years.
So I've learned from many and tried to listen as much as I could.
This is where I am. Sometimes I think, how in the world did I ever think I could do this? But it's happened.
Now we do need to do a little because Seals done such a good job of helping me manage that.
We now need more pools, we need more lodging, but it will never be like a huge resort. That's not what we're here for sure.
I did it. I thought I was doing it to benefit the healing of others.
And I became healed in the process. You never think that's going to happen.
And we're never totally there, but there's always something more to learn and grow about.
But my whole vision, mission statement, has been to allow the healing waters and the therapists we have, therapies we have to uplift the spirits and open the hearts of all who come.
So beautiful.
That they might remember who they are, where they came from and what they came to do.
I don't really publish that part. But that's kind of in the background because we all are here for a purpose.
And sometimes we forget that.
And I think just being exposed to the healing waters, the mountains, the landscape, it just feels like sacred land and it puts you into, only if you want to, you can go as deep as you want.
Or not. Just come for relax and visit.
And that's it.
You know, I feel so fortunate to have lived in Colorado for so many years with many different healing hot springs.
And of course, in other parts of the country, other parts of the world, access isn't necessarily quite as easy as we have it around here.
And that said, I am also struck that in so many traditions all around the planet, getting into the waters for healing is essential.

Right. So the Mickva tradition of the hebraic culture, the ways that people interact with water in the Islamic world prior to going into the mosque, the bath houses of the Middle East Mediterranean region.
And of course, hot springs around Turtle Island, the Americas here have been sacred to so many different tribes over time periods that some of us probably don't really even know.
And I'm struck that more and more of us in our culture as our cultures in the process of healing are connecting to the water in this mindful and deep heartfelt way.
And my own personal experience tells me that our relationship with water is critical. It's essential.
And clearly you are embodying that and exhibiting and articulating that.
I'm wondering what kinds of transformations have you seen in others who come here and experiences perhaps for the first time in their lives?
Is that something you get to witness?
Yes. I'm not here all the time anymore, but we, many times we hear stories about how it's affected people, how they have.
And also some of our deeper therapies that we've had for them can also assist with the waters. It's amazing. It's such a joy to hear that.
